div.p: For the past decade I've traveled around the country deploying big data solutions to hundreds of Splunk customers. Analytics is one of my passions: I love digging into the data and teasing out interesting observations you'd otherwise miss.

The idea to build this app came from years of mentoring consultants. I found that teaching engineers the nuts and bolts of a platform is relatively easy . However, when faced with a complex challenge or sophisticated dataset I often see consultants get stuck:

ul.li: Who is the audience you're seeking to serve?
What meaningful questions are you trying to answer?
What process or approach best serves the customer's needs?

div.p: I developed this app to teach engineers how to think. Building apps and visualizing data are my paintbrush and canvas. It's my art. I hope that by pulling back the curtain and showing you the process will make you a better big data practitioner.

li.a: Planning Ahead - Tips & approach for developing a Splunk app
Static Reports are Dead. Why all Splunk dashboards should be interactive
Listen to your customers! Incorporating feedback into your Splunk Use Cases

div.p: Start off by visiting the Uber Executive Dashboard. This will give you high-level insights into key metrics. It'll also give you a chance to get familiar with the data.
When you're ready for a deep dive take look at the advanced use cases. These are tough questions I came up with and used Splunk searches to answer:

ul.li: What time of year do I ride the most?
Is there a correlation between time and price?
Historical trending of total rides vs. cost?
How long do I wait around for uber?

div.p: What questions did you come up with? What additional use cases can you build with this data? I've open-sourced the code and made the data publicly available. Try developing additional use cases and contribute back to the community.
